entries.title: The Toll of Capturing El Chapo’s Son: 10 Soldiers, 19 Cartel Members Dead
entries.description: After troops arrested a son of the notorious drug lord known as El Chapo, cartel gunmen tried to free him, resulting in a series of gun battles and thousands of troops called into the fight.

entries.title: Biden Moves to End Doughnut Lures and Other Bear Hunting Tactics in Alaska
entries.description: A new rule proposed by the administration would also bar hunters from invading wolf dens to kill pups.

entries.title: Prince Harry Claims in Memoir to Have Killed 25 in Afghanistan
entries.description: After British news outlets revealed details from his memoir about his military service, Afghan officials and some in the British military expressed criticism.

entries.title: New Armored Vehicles Will Help Ukraine Take the Fight to Russia
entries.description: The Western allies’ provision of infantry fighting vehicles signals their support for new offensives in coming months, analysts said.

entries.title: Attacks Continue in Ukraine Despite Russia’s Supposed Cease-Fire
entries.description: Ukraine never accepted Russia’s unilateral Christmas truce, dismissing it as a hollow ploy, and Russian shelling was as intense as ever in a hotly contested city.

entries.title: Ukraine Says Allies No Longer View Giving Key Weapons as ‘Taboo’
entries.description: The foreign minister, Dmytro Kuleba, welcomed pledges this week from France, Germany and the United States of military aid that his government had been seeking for months.

entries.title: Kenyan Gay Rights Activist, Edwin Chiloba, Is Killed
entries.description: Edwin Chiloba’s body was dumped on the roadside by a moving vehicle in the country’s west. Police have arrested his friend and are pursuing two others in the case.

entries.title: The U.S. announces a $3 billion package of military aid to Ukraine, including Bradley Fighting Vehicles.
entries.description: Karine Jean-Pierre, the White House press secretary, said the administration would also send $682 million to countries on NATO’s eastern flank.

entries.title: Nate Thayer, Bold Reporter Who Interviewed Pol Pot, Dies at 62
entries.description: The “mad genius” journalist scored an exclusive interview with the genocidal Cambodian leader and covered his show trial, another worldwide scoop.

entries.title: Marcio Freire, Renowned Brazilian Surfer, Dies in Portugal
entries.description: Mr. Freire began surfing at an early age and starred in a 2016 documentary on the sport. He was 47.

entries.title: Biden Administration Moves to Tighten Limits on Deadly Air Pollution
entries.description: A new rule would, for the first time in a decade, reduce emissions of soot that disproportionately harm communities of color.

entries.title: Belarus Leader Visits a Military Base Where Russian Forces Are Stationed
entries.description: Concerns have mounted in recent weeks that Moscow could try to draw Belarus, Ukraine’s northern neighbor, more directly into the war.

entries.title: These Engineers Want to Build Conscious Robots. Others Say It’s a Bad Idea.
entries.description: The pursuit of robot consciousness may be humankind’s next moonshot. But it comes with a slurry of difficult questions.

entries.title: Military Investigation Reveals How the U.S. Botched a Drone Strike in Kabul
entries.description: Documents obtained through a lawsuit reveal how biases led to the deadly August 2021 blunder, and that officials made misleading statements concealing their assessment of civilian casualties.

entries.title: As Russia Calls a Cease-Fire, Its Forces Keep Up the Attack
entries.description: In Kherson, a fire station was shelled and at least one person was killed in the hours before a planned Russian cease-fire began. Ukraine and its allies have dismissed the move as posturing.

entries.title: The Lying Congressman
entries.description: George Santos is stretching the tolerance for lies in U.S. politics.

entries.title: Here Are the People Iran Sentenced to Death in Its Protest Crackdown
entries.description: An updated look at the Iranians marked for execution in the government’s attempt to curb a monthslong uprising.

entries.title: She Is Africa’s First Heat Officer. Can She Make Her City Livable?
entries.description: Eugenia Kargbo remembers when Sierra Leone’s capital was greener and cooler, and is now trying to help the city combat rising temperatures.

entries.title: China’s Covid Surge Threatens Villages as Lunar New Year Approaches
entries.description: Millions are expected to travel home this month, spreading Covid to rural communities where health care services are woefully underdeveloped.

entries.title: What Is the Bradley Fighting Vehicle?
entries.description: Often mistaken for a tank, the decades-old Bradley offers a compromise between traditional tank firepower and an armored personnel carrier.

entries.title: Can Australia Escape a Recession?
entries.description: “Whether it’s a technical recession or not, we certainly are going to be in for difficult times,” one economist said.

entries.title: Battered and Strained by War, Ukraine’s Economy Adapts to Survive
entries.description: After 10 months of Russian destruction, Ukraine’s economy shrank by 30 percent. But companies have packed up and moved, switched products and found support abroad.

entries.title: Your Friday Briefing
entries.description: Responses to Russia’s ordering of a cease-fire.

entries.title: Putin Calls a 36-Hour Cease-Fire, but Ukraine and U.S. Are Skeptical
entries.description: The cease-fire would coincide with the Eastern Orthodox Christmas on Saturday, but Kremlin adversaries and some analysts call it a ploy for military and political advantage.
